SUTTIR
VOL. XXI, NO. 7.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 20, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HAVERFORD DEFEATS 'VARSITY

CHEMICAL LAB. TO BE MOVED

HOPKINS ALUMNUS IS GOVERNOR

NIGHT PRACTICE TELLS ON TEAM

Aerial Attack Responsible for Conquering of the Black and Blue by
the Score of 14 to 7—Game
Hotly Contested.

After Christmas, All Undergraduate
Classes in Chemistry Will Be Housed
in the Basement of the Mechani
cal Engineering Building.

Dr. Charles Brough, Victorious Candidate at Recent Arkansas Gubernatorial Election, Received His Ph.
D.from Hopkins in 1898.

Haverford Game Again Emphasizes Need
of Daylight Scrimmages — St.
John's Game to Be a
Hard One.

An array of forward passes,
executed with great skill and precision at various stages of the
game, enabled Haverford to defeat
Hopkins at Homewood last Saturday, 14 to 7.
Seldom have the spectators been
given such an excellent exhibition
of the aerial variety of football as
that staged by the visitors on Sat• urday. Haverford made the discovery early in the game that it
was next to impossible to gain
through the Black and Blue line.
Thereupon, the Quakers tried out
the aerial style of play, and finding this successful, they proceeded
to complete during the remainder
of the contest, forward passes of
every kind and description for
both long and short gains, that
finally brought victory to Haverford and spelt defeat for Hopkins.
It looked like a tie game at the
latter part of the final period,
when the score stood 7 to 7. Then
Haverford pulled off the unexpected. An exchange of punts resulted in the visitors' ball on the
Black and Blue 35-yard line. In
the few remaining minutes of
play, a series of. beautiful forward
passes and several line plunges,
and the Quakers had scored an
additional touchdown.
There was no scoring during
the first half. The period was featured, for the most part, by a
vigorous punting duel, with Leadbetter in the stellar role for Hopkins, and Crossman for Haverford. Haverford lost a chance to
score at the beginning of the second quarter due to the excellent
work of Doc Brooks. The Quakers
completed a forward pass which
brought the ball to Hopkins' 20yard line, and then advanced it to
the 7-yard line. It looked like a
sure touchdown for the visitors.
But the Black and Blue line
braced, and on the next three
plays, Haverford failed to gain.
With but one down left in which
to score, the Quakers threw a low
pass which was caught by Chandler. However, Brooks nailed him,
and the ball went to Hopkins on
downs, with the pigskin a few
inches inside the goal line. There
was little action during the remainder of the period.
The visitors made the first score
of the game shortly after the
opening of the second half. A long
pass from the center of the field,
Crossman to Chandler, put the
ball on Hopkins' 20-yard. line.

According to plans recently
adopted, all the undergraduate
laboratory work in chemistry will
be moved to Homewood by January 1. The University officials
have definitely decided on the
move, and work will be b'egun in
installing the new laboratory as
soon as the equipment can be obtained from the manufacturers.
The laboratory will be situated
in the south end of the basement
of the Mechanical Engineering
Building. This will be the home
of the undergraduate chemistry
department until funds are available for the erection of the main
chemical laboratory at the northeast corner of the main quadrangle.
Doctor Gilpin,who has had charge
of selecting the new apparatus
and arranging the laboratory, has
stated that the equipment used
will be entirely new, with the exception of such supplies of chemicals, bottles, tubing, etc., as can
be easily transported to Homewood. The new equipment has
been designed with a view to a
whole new chemical building at
Homewood. When such a laboratory is built, the apparatus to be
put in the basement of the Mechanical Engineering Building
will be moved to it.
Doctor Gilpin and Doctor Miller will have charge of the new
laboratory, where all the undergraduate classes will be housed.
All three classes will necessarily
be in the one room at Homewood,
but each class will be isolated in
a different part of the room. The
graduate students will still have
to pursue their work downtown
in the old laboratory, until a
whole new chemical building can
be erected at Homewood.
The new laboratory arrangement will solve many of the problems confronting the chemical department at present. The next
advantage is that the undergraduates will no longer have to go
from Homewood down town for
their laboratory work.
Besides the new equipment, especially made to order after the
designs of Doctor Gilpin, the
basement of the Mechanical Engineering Building will contain
a chemical stock and supply room
and an office.
The actual moving will be done
during the Christmas holidays,
the laboratory work in the new
quarters starting when the University routine is resumed on
January 3.

Charles Hillman Brough, Ph.
D., LL. D., the successful candidate for governor of Arkansas in
the recent election, was a graduate student in economics at Johns
Hopkins for three years and received his degree from this University. He is well remembered
by the professors under whom he
worked both for his attractive
personality and his brilliancy in
studies.
Doctor Brough was born in Mississippi in 1876, the son of Charles
M. Brough. He attended Mississippi College, where he received
his A. B. in 1894. He came here
in the autumn of 1895 to become
a graduate student in economics,
becoming a fellow in that subject
in 1897, and receiving his Ph. D.
in June, 1898. Mr. Brougli then
became professor of economics in
Mississippi College, where he remained until 1901. He was
awarded an LL. D. by the University of Mississippi in 1902, and,
the same year became professor
of economics at Hillman College.
The following year he was appointed professor of economics
and sociology at the University of
Arkansas. He held this position
until he resigned in order to run
for the governorship.
Doctor Brough was the Democratic candidate. In the Democratic primary, held last March,
he received as many votes as his
two opponents combined. He is a
strong supporter of President
Wilson, having organized in 1912
the Arkansas branch of the Woodrow Wilson College Men's League.
He canvassed Arkansas, Tennessee Maine, Illinois, and several
other States in Wilson's behalf in
the recent campaign, and it is
considered that much of the credit
for the Democratic landslide in
Arkansas should be given to Doctor Brough.
The governor-elect's entrance
into Arkansas politics was partly
due to his numerous speeches
at high school commencements
throughout the State. He was
proposed for the governorship in
1914, but withdrew in favor of
another candidate. He was bitterly attacked during his campaign because of a dissertation
defending Mormomism, written
while ht Johns Hopkins as a partfial fulfillment of the requirements for his Ph. D.
Doctor Brough's literary contributions have, in the main, been

The team was defeated Saturday in a game that for a long
time seemed destined to end in a
tie score, but Haverford in
the last few minutes of play
opened up a forward pass attack
with which the Hopkins defense
was utterly unable to cope and
which gave Haverford the touchdown that decided the game in
their favor. This exhibition of
forward passing was, without
doubt, the best ever seen in this
part of the country and is indicative of what can be done with
such a method of attack, executed
as it was Saturday.
Sincere criticism was made of
our defense against this play
Saturday as was of our failure
to utilize such an attack, and in
justice to the team some explanation is necessary. Forward passing requires careful and persistent practice, and most of all it requires daylight. Dr. Bennett, the
Haverford coach, infoimed the
writer that hours were spent on
this play before it was perfected
and that he considered it useless
to try to practice it after dark.
To be sure, our team is equipped
with forward-pass plays, and ones
the efficacy of which has been well
tested, but the daylight needed
for their perfection is lacking.
Had we the power of Joshua, conditions might be altered, but as
it is, our forward-pass practice is
held under most unpromising conditions. The same requisites are
needed for defense against the
pass as for its development.
Nevertheless, work is going on in
this phase of the game, and it is
hoped that in the next two games
some good results will be shown.
In the straight frontal attack
our team showed up exceedingly
well, for they at least held their
own, while on defense against
rushing, we had a shade on Haverford, and this despite the fact
that the line work as a whole was
not so good as in the Western
Maryland game. That game took
a great deal out of the men and
a more or less conscious let-down
was necessary last week in order
to have the men gradually round
into shape.
The backfield has not yet
reached the form desired, as they
are not properly picking the holes
and are not helping each other
enough in interference. However,
slow development is apparent and

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 20, 1916.

BENEFIT TO BE GALA OCCASION
Record Attendance Expected at Hullabaloo Theatre Party and Dance
on the Eve of the St. John's
Football Game.

HARVARD AND LEHIGH ON
HOPKINS BASEBALL SCHEDULE

The schedule of the baseball
team for this season has not been
completed, but Manager Pitt has
announced that he has some splendid engagements and has others
in view. When complete, the
schedule should comprise fourteen
games. Games with Harvard and
Lehigh have been already arranged, and, in general, Hopkins
will meet larger and better opponents than in former years.
Under the leadership of Captain Defandorf, with only two
serious losses (those of Ewing
and Lednum) and with a great
deal of prospective material, this
year's team should be unusually
good. Last year's captain, Ewing, will be greatly missed at
third base, and a good outfielder
must be found to replace Lednum.
Practice in the batting cage will
probably begin immediately after
the Christmas holidays.

The Hullabaloo benefit and
dance will be held this Friday
evening at the Academy of Music.
Otis Skinner in "Mr. Antonio"—
a play that has been much praised
by many of the critics throughout
the country—will be the attraction, and more students and
graduates than have ever attended
a Hopkins benefit are expected to
be present when the curtain rises.
The day selected happened to be
the eve of the St. John's game and
the Academy will ring in the intermissions with songs and cheers
for Hopkins.
Immediately after the end of
the performance the Hopkins students and their friends will adjourn to the hall above the playhouse, where an informal dance
John Kendrick Bangs, the
will be held. The (lancing will noted humorist, is giving a lecstart about 11 o'clock and will ture course at the New Hampcontinue until 1.30.

ELEVEN 'VARSITY MEN ELIGIBLE
A Great Part of Last Year's Lacrosse
Team Can Take the Field Again.
Schedule to Be Soon
Announced.

The lacrosse team will hold its
organization meeting immediately
after the close of the football season, probably some time during
the first week in December. Light
practice in goal shooting and
stickwork to get the men in condition will be held in the cage
until after the Christmas holidays, when the hard work will
begin.
The outlook for the team this
year is'unusually bright eleven
men who have already won their
"H's" in lacrosse remain in the
University, and will be eligible
for the league games, in which
there is a four-year rule. These
men are: Capt. J. C. Knipp, exCapt. Paul Sutton, Stuart, Baker,
Brooks, Meyer, Schmidt, Woodward, Wolfe, Hoffman and F. Sutton. These men, with several of
last year's substitutes and new
men who have entered the University this fall, should make an
exceptionally strong combination,
fully up to the standards of Hopkins' teams of the past.
Manager Randolph Smith has
not yet announced his schedule,
but he will publish it in THE
NEWS-LETTER as SOOR as all the
details are arranged. According
to the custom of the lacrosse
league, Hopkins will play Swarthmore at Swarthmore this year,
while Lehigh comes to Baltimore.
GLEE CLUB STILL HAS OPEN
PLACES FOR NEW MATERIAL

The Glee Club rehearsals have
been evidencing highly satisfactory progress of late, but there
is still a shortage of men which
the director wishes'to decrease before he picks the singers who will
have fixed places in the club. As
soon as the club is picked, no
changes will be made, each member remaining in it throughout the
whole concert season. Rehearsals
for the present are held in the
large assembly hall of the Civil
Engineering Building at 8 o'clock
every Thursday evening.
In the last few rehearsals the
Hopkins songs to be sung in the
coming concerts have been reviewed and preparations have
been made for the learning of
some new classical pieces. The
management is working out an
excellent schedule for the year.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 20, 1916.

WANTS CHANGE IN AGREEMENT

MANY OUT FOR BASKETBALL TEAM

U.of Va.Asks Debating Council to Agree
to Alteration of the Conditions of
Triangle—Hopkins Insists Upon
Present Stipulations.

All Positions W111 Be Hotly Contested
Season Opens December 16, with a
Game at the Naval Academy,
Annapolis.

At the first meeting of the Debate Council last Wednesday,
what was expected to be a mere
formal ratification of the triangular debate which has been in existence for four years between the
universities of North Carolina
and Virginia and Hopkins developed into an important discussion on just how to meet a telegram from Virginia which asked
for fundamental changes in the
present agreement.
Since the triangle was founded,
it has been the invariable custom
for each university to send out
two teams, neither of which debated on its home territory. The
objects of this system were the
insuring of impartial debates, the
facilitating of the selection of
judges, and the establishment of
broader and more intimate relations between the three universities. These conditions have
proved exceptionally satisfactory
in the past, and their fairness has
been so evident, that the agreement was printed in full in a recent Intercollegiate Debate Book
as a model for the use of other institutions. During the past three
years, each debating season has
been begun by a quick ratification
of this agreement by all three universities. Just before the meeting
of the Council last week, however,
Dr. French received a telegram
from the Univeisity of Virginia,
asking that this year the agreement be so modified as to permit
one team from each university to
debate on its own ground.
After consultation, the Hopkins
Council came to the unanimous
argeement that such a change, in
their opinion, was inadvisable,
and a night letter to that effect
was immediately dispatched to
Virginia. No answer to that letter has as yet been received, and
it is therefore not known whether
Virginia will withdraw its request, or whether it will insist
upon the new conditions, even to
the breaking up of the triangle.
With the night letter to Virginia, a letter was dispatched to
North Carolina, asking if the
agreement was still satisfactory
to that university. As no objection from that quarter has been
heard, the Council deems it probable that the authorities at
Chapel Hill are behind the agreement as it stands, which fact, if
it be confirmed, will strengthen
Hopkins' position considerably.
While desirous that the triangle be continued, if possible, under the old conditions, Hopkins
has nothing to fear even were it
to be dissolved. The record of
three successive victories which it
holds will insure it debates with
other colleges and universities of

The Hqpkins Independent Basket-ball Team is well on the road
to organization. The schedule is
almost complete, and the available material for the team is of
an exceptionally fine calibre.
Since last week many playei.s
not considered in the original list
have told Pfitsch, captain and
manager, that they intended to
come out. Among these are Love,
a forward and captain of last
year's sophomore team; Joe Branham, who played guard on the
Washington College team for several seasons; Smith, a center from
Randolph Macon College; Littman, a guard on last year's City
College team; Wood, a forward
from Swarthmore Preparatory
School; and Cashell, formerly a
forward on the Rockhill High
School five.
Practice will begin some time
this week for those men that are
not out for the football team. A
place in which to practice has
been secured, but for the present
the name of the hall will only be
announced to the players.
In addition to the games that
were announced in last week's issue of THE NEWS-LETTER, another
contest has been booked. The independents will play the Naval
Academy at Annapolis on December 16. This will be the opening
game of the season, which will
continue until April 1.
While the present lineup of the
five is a remarkably good one
—with Brooks and Cox, guards;
Pfitsch, center; and Shureich and
Buchness playing the forward positions—several of the new men
are brilliant players and a hot
fight for the positions is expected.
Six or seven men will be carried
on all of the trips.
Menorah Study Circles Flourishing.

The Johns Hopkins Menorah
Society is having an unusually
successful season. At the first
meeting, there was an attendance
of almost fifty, and more are expected at the second. Two study
circles, these in modern Hebrew,
are already well under way; the
third, due to the conflict between
its hour and the time of the
Wednesday mass-meetings, has
been deferred until after Thanksgiving.

Medical School Alumnius Marries.

Dr. Paul W. Harrison, a graduate of Johns Hopkins Medical
School and for several years head
of medical missionary work in
Arabia, was recently married to
Miss Regina Rabbe. The ceremony, which was performed by
the Rev. Dr. Ezra K. Bell, took
place at the First English Lutheran Church. Dr. Harrison and his
wife left for Arabia on November 18.

which they are in favor, the entire
discussion should be dropped
automatically, and the board be
left free to follow its policy. If
the class decides that they wish
the traditional nature of the Hullabaloo to be preserved,the change
in policy should be revoked. In
either case, before the Hullabaloo
board proceeds further with its
plan, it should correct what, in
either eventuality, has been a
grave misconception of function—
it should discover the sentiment
of the men who elected it.
In such a class discussion, one
thing must be borne in mind. The
book which will be published at
the end of the year will be either
a senior class book or it will be
an undergraduate annual. The
issue is clear-cut—and it must be
so presented by the Hullabaloo
board. The Hullabaloos of the
past have represented all University activities, and yet have been
senior books; a change from the
policy under which those books
were conceived, a change which
has been deemed important enough
to be announced individually to
every undergraduate, cannot be
misinterpreted. A book conceived
as an undergraduate annual cannot,.in the nature of things, still
be a senior book. The members of
the Class of 1917 must pass a vote
of approval or disapproval upon
the policy of the Hullabaloo
board, but, what is more important, they should have made clear
to them exactly upon what they
are voting.
The question is too vital a one
to permit of ambiguity or of misunderstanding. If 1917 is to issue
an annual instead of a class book,
it must be done so with a full
knowledge on the part of every
man of the difference which lies
between the two.
In the opinion of THE NEWSLETTER, the reason for the entire
change of policy meditated by the
1917 Hullabaloo Board is amply
explained by one phrase — "Hopkins' traditions are nil." In that
phrase is expressed the great
danger which, more than any
other, the Hopkins of the future
will have to overcome. The Hopkins undergraduates of the past,
it is true, have never worn little
black and blue caps during their
freshman years, nor have their
senior classes published books resplendent in myriad photographs
and pages. But the Hopkins of
the past has meant something,
meant something far too important to be nullified by the opinions
of any board or of any class. It
has not been a matter of the obvious, flaunting customs of the
typical small college; it has been
a matter of outlook, of understanding, of appreciation. The
thing against which Hopkins has
to guard today is not a matter of
growing too slowly, it is a matter
of growing too fast. Discardance
is too perilously easy; the need of
the Hopkins of today is preservation.

A Matter for Class Action.

takes great
pleasure in publishing, on another
page, the letter from the editorin-chief of the Hullabaloo—both
for the obvious consideration of
justice involved, and for the fact
that, with that letter, the entire
question of the advisability of the
change in policy recently announced by the 1917 Hullabaloo
Board is crystallized in such a
form as to permit of immediate
action. .
Devoid of all argument and rhetoric, the facts of the situation
are as follows: (1) Basing its decision upon the premises that
"Hopkins has never had a creditable year book" and that "Hopkins traditions are nil," the 1917
Hullabaloo Board has planned to
convert the Hullabaloo from a
senior class book to "an undergraduate annual." (2) The title of
the book is to be changed from
"The 1917 Hullabaloo" to "The
Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo." (3)
Neither the change in nature or in
title has been voted upon by the
senior class.
In this last fact lies the crux
of the situation. An alteration in
the fudamental idea of one of the
oldest of Hopkins' institutions is
too important a matter to be undertaken without the express approval of the class to whom the
editors of the Hullabaloo are always responsible. If that class decides that the change is one of
THE NEWS-LETTER

The Hullabaloos of the past
have had a definite meaning—
they have not been publications
whose success has been measured
by their sale. They have been
books which have meant something to the few, rather than
meant nothing to the many. They
have represented the classes by
whom they were published, as the
Hullabaloo of 1917 should represent the class by whom it is published, and, in so doing, they have
represented the spirit of the University far better than could
have—an undergraduate annual.
The change of policy of their
Hullabaloo is a matter to be decided by the. Class of 1917.
Whether 1917 experiment in
change or whether it does not,
THE NEWS-LETTER ventures the
prophecy that the senior classes
of the future, inevitably, will revert to the old conception—a Hullabaloo of the senior class. But
to the members of the 1917 class,
the matter is none the less a vital
one, for, to them, there will be
only one Hullabaloo—it is for
them to determine whether the
book they publish is to be a book
which belongs peculiarly to them,
or a book, which, perchance, will
bring slightly increased sales as
"an undergraduate annual."
Basket-ball.

In the matfer of independent
teams, Hopkins occupies a somewhat peculiar position in that the
lack of funds at the disposal of
the Athletic Association makes
impossible the recognition of
some minor sports which, at other
universities, are fully acknowledged. This position, however, is
fully known, and the independent
teams which Hopkins produces
are viewed, not as outlaw aggregations, but rather as teams
which are undergoing a period of
probation before the expense entailed by their recognition can
be undertaken.
It is this place which the independent swimming team has occupied for the last few years, and in
which it is now to be joined by
the independent basket-ball team.
The organization of those teams
is no easy matter, and the men
who are responsible for such organization are all the more entitled to praise, in that they
know that, for some time at least,
their efforts must go unrewarded.
There is at Hopkins an unusually
large number of good basket-ball
players, and the enthusiasm with
which these players have answered
the call for volunteers is a rather
encouraging augury that if the
basket-ball team this year will not
represent the University in name
it will at least represent it in
merit.

PRIZES TO BE AWARDED
FOR BEST BOTANICAL ESSAYS

Lewis and Valentine Company,
landscape gardeners and nursery
experts, have offered prizes for
the best essays on old Suffruticosa boxwood. The amounts of the
prizes range from $100 to $25.
The winning essays will be published in a garden magazine forming a series of articles on the boxwood.
Dean Brush, who has charge of
the competition at Homewood,
will provide for the selection of
the two best essays from those
entered. The essays are to be
handed in before January 1. Material for the essay can be obtained from Doctor Johnson, of
the botanical department.
Seymour Merrick,'11, Found Dead.

Samuel Seymour Merrick, who
graduated from Johns Hopkins in
1911; died last Friday morning at
his home, 824 Park avenue. His
death was caused by asphyxiation, due to the accidental extinguishing of the fire in the gas
logs in his room. He was the son
of Dr. Samuel K. Merrick, nose
and throat specialist, and the
brother of William S. Merrick,
also a Hopkins graduate; and
Robert G. Merrick, of this year's
senior class. While at Hopkins,
Seymour Merrick was one of the
most popular men in the studentbody.

COMPANIES TO BE RE-FORMED
Lack of Men Will Necessitate Reduction
of Battalion from Four Companies to
Three—Uniforms Will Probably
Arrive This Week.

The orders for the uniforms of
all the men in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps who have
paid for them were sent in last
Saturday, and it is hoped that
they will arrive before the St
John's game. As soon as the uni
forms arrive, three companies will
be formed in place of the four
now existing.
On last Friday two drills were
held so that all men desiring to
go to the Polytechnic-City College
game could do so. Besides the
regular drill at 4.30 one was held
in the morning at 7.55. r.
A great part of the time- recently has been spent in perfecting battalion drill. The movements have not been executed
with the precision that might be
expected, but it is hoped that a
high degree of excellence will
soon be attained.
It has been published in a recent bulletin of the War Department that the next examinations
of candidates for provisional appointment as second lieutenant
in the line of the Army, will begin on January 29, 1917.
Applicants for authority to
take this examination should
forward their applications to the
Adjutant-General of the Army at
as early a date as practicable,
and in any event, in time to reach
the Adjutant-General's office not
later than January 15, 1917, as
applications received after that
date may be too late for proper
consideration in connection with
the examination.
As there are now a large number of vacancies in the Army,
this examination offers an excellent opportunity for men between
the ages of 21 and 27 to enter as
second lieutenants. -The pay of a
second lieutenant is $1,700 yearly.
Another appeal has been made
for more enlistments. If 60 more
men would enroll, the reorganization of the battalion into three
companies would be unnecessary.
It is hoped that a large number
of the physical exercise class and
the football candidates will enroll in the near future.
The University of St. Louis has
adopted a novel form of freNknansophomore contest. The rules provide for a seven-foot wood stockade surrounding a 14-foot wooden
flagpole, upon which the sophomores will place their banner. In
breaking into this stockade, in
which the sophomores are stationed, the freshmen will not be
allowed to use battering rams or
weapons of any description. The
sophomores are to be provided
with ropes.—Ex.

Some very interesting moving
pictures of the American Ambulance Corps in field service will

in the lecture hall of
be
Engineering Building
l
Civi
the
the'
on Tuesday, November 28, at 5
o'clock.
The pictures were taken by the
French Government and were presented to the American Ambulance Field Service in appreciation and recognition of its excellent assistance in attending to the
wounded. At present there are
about two hundred American ambulances in the French Army,
which are divided into four sections—one in Flanders, one in Alsace, one in the Somme region
and one at Verdun. They are supported largely by wealthy gitizens
of the United States.
The entire operation of the ambulances is carried on by students
from many of our big universities, such as Harvard, Yale and
Princeton. So excellent have been
their services that many have
been awarded "the Cross of War"
or the "Military Medal"—honors
not easily won. Moreover, they
have been appointed the official
lifters of the wounded on account
of their gentleness and ability.
Three of the Baltimore boys are
Emory Niles, Leonard Ober and
Johnson Okrick.
Consequent to their invaluable
aid, the French Government wants
another section to post at Saloniki and in order to fulfill this,
desire, the American Ambulance
Field Service is endeavoring to recruit more men.
In order to attain that end,
these moving pidures are being
shown in the United States, with
the hope that a large number of
young men will offer their serv
ices to the corps. The pictures are
being shown in Baltimore under
the auspices of the local committee of the American Fund for
French Wounded, of which Miss
Louise Dawson is chairman. This
society is affiliated with the
American Ambulance Field Service.
Besides the exhibition, on next
Tuesday at Homewood, the moving pictures will be also displayed
at the Johns Hopkins Medical
School and at the Lyceum Theater
on this Friday at 8.30. On the
latter occasion, Mr. Lisle Buswell
will speak on the work • of the
corps and will tell of his experiences at the front.
It is the hope of these societies
that a large number of Hopkins •
men will see these pictures of
their fellow-students at the front,
and that sonic will enlist in the
American Ambulance Field Service.
A bequest of $20,000 has been
left to the University of Oberlin
to enable the student body to hear
the finest speakers that can be
procured.—Ex.

SUTTIR
VOL. XXI, NO. 7.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 20, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HAVERFORD DEFEATS 'VARSITY

CHEMICAL LAB. TO BE MOVED

HOPKINS ALUMNUS IS GOVERNOR

NIGHT PRACTICE TELLS ON TEAM

Aerial Attack Responsible for Conquering of the Black and Blue by
the Score of 14 to 7—Game
Hotly Contested.

After Christmas, All Undergraduate
Classes in Chemistry Will Be Housed
in the Basement of the Mechani
cal Engineering Building.

Dr. Charles Brough, Victorious Candidate at Recent Arkansas Gubernatorial Election, Received His Ph.
D.from Hopkins in 1898.

Haverford Game Again Emphasizes Need
of Daylight Scrimmages — St.
John's Game to Be a
Hard One.

An array of forward passes,
executed with great skill and precision at various stages of the
game, enabled Haverford to defeat
Hopkins at Homewood last Saturday, 14 to 7.
Seldom have the spectators been
given such an excellent exhibition
of the aerial variety of football as
that staged by the visitors on Sat• urday. Haverford made the discovery early in the game that it
was next to impossible to gain
through the Black and Blue line.
Thereupon, the Quakers tried out
the aerial style of play, and finding this successful, they proceeded
to complete during the remainder
of the contest, forward passes of
every kind and description for
both long and short gains, that
finally brought victory to Haverford and spelt defeat for Hopkins.
It looked like a tie game at the
latter part of the final period,
when the score stood 7 to 7. Then
Haverford pulled off the unexpected. An exchange of punts resulted in the visitors' ball on the
Black and Blue 35-yard line. In
the few remaining minutes of
play, a series of. beautiful forward
passes and several line plunges,
and the Quakers had scored an
additional touchdown.
There was no scoring during
the first half. The period was featured, for the most part, by a
vigorous punting duel, with Leadbetter in the stellar role for Hopkins, and Crossman for Haverford. Haverford lost a chance to
score at the beginning of the second quarter due to the excellent
work of Doc Brooks. The Quakers
completed a forward pass which
brought the ball to Hopkins' 20yard line, and then advanced it to
the 7-yard line. It looked like a
sure touchdown for the visitors.
But the Black and Blue line
braced, and on the next three
plays, Haverford failed to gain.
With but one down left in which
to score, the Quakers threw a low
pass which was caught by Chandler. However, Brooks nailed him,
and the ball went to Hopkins on
downs, with the pigskin a few
inches inside the goal line. There
was little action during the remainder of the period.
The visitors made the first score
of the game shortly after the
opening of the second half. A long
pass from the center of the field,
Crossman to Chandler, put the
ball on Hopkins' 20-yard. line.

According to plans recently
adopted, all the undergraduate
laboratory work in chemistry will
be moved to Homewood by January 1. The University officials
have definitely decided on the
move, and work will be b'egun in
installing the new laboratory as
soon as the equipment can be obtained from the manufacturers.
The laboratory will be situated
in the south end of the basement
of the Mechanical Engineering
Building. This will be the home
of the undergraduate chemistry
department until funds are available for the erection of the main
chemical laboratory at the northeast corner of the main quadrangle.
Doctor Gilpin,who has had charge
of selecting the new apparatus
and arranging the laboratory, has
stated that the equipment used
will be entirely new, with the exception of such supplies of chemicals, bottles, tubing, etc., as can
be easily transported to Homewood. The new equipment has
been designed with a view to a
whole new chemical building at
Homewood. When such a laboratory is built, the apparatus to be
put in the basement of the Mechanical Engineering Building
will be moved to it.
Doctor Gilpin and Doctor Miller will have charge of the new
laboratory, where all the undergraduate classes will be housed.
All three classes will necessarily
be in the one room at Homewood,
but each class will be isolated in
a different part of the room. The
graduate students will still have
to pursue their work downtown
in the old laboratory, until a
whole new chemical building can
be erected at Homewood.
The new laboratory arrangement will solve many of the problems confronting the chemical department at present. The next
advantage is that the undergraduates will no longer have to go
from Homewood down town for
their laboratory work.
Besides the new equipment, especially made to order after the
designs of Doctor Gilpin, the
basement of the Mechanical Engineering Building will contain
a chemical stock and supply room
and an office.
The actual moving will be done
during the Christmas holidays,
the laboratory work in the new
quarters starting when the University routine is resumed on
January 3.

Charles Hillman Brough, Ph.
D., LL. D., the successful candidate for governor of Arkansas in
the recent election, was a graduate student in economics at Johns
Hopkins for three years and received his degree from this University. He is well remembered
by the professors under whom he
worked both for his attractive
personality and his brilliancy in
studies.
Doctor Brough was born in Mississippi in 1876, the son of Charles
M. Brough. He attended Mississippi College, where he received
his A. B. in 1894. He came here
in the autumn of 1895 to become
a graduate student in economics,
becoming a fellow in that subject
in 1897, and receiving his Ph. D.
in June, 1898. Mr. Brougli then
became professor of economics in
Mississippi College, where he remained until 1901. He was
awarded an LL. D. by the University of Mississippi in 1902, and,
the same year became professor
of economics at Hillman College.
The following year he was appointed professor of economics
and sociology at the University of
Arkansas. He held this position
until he resigned in order to run
for the governorship.
Doctor Brough was the Democratic candidate. In the Democratic primary, held last March,
he received as many votes as his
two opponents combined. He is a
strong supporter of President
Wilson, having organized in 1912
the Arkansas branch of the Woodrow Wilson College Men's League.
He canvassed Arkansas, Tennessee Maine, Illinois, and several
other States in Wilson's behalf in
the recent campaign, and it is
considered that much of the credit
for the Democratic landslide in
Arkansas should be given to Doctor Brough.
The governor-elect's entrance
into Arkansas politics was partly
due to his numerous speeches
at high school commencements
throughout the State. He was
proposed for the governorship in
1914, but withdrew in favor of
another candidate. He was bitterly attacked during his campaign because of a dissertation
defending Mormomism, written
while ht Johns Hopkins as a partfial fulfillment of the requirements for his Ph. D.

was utterly unable to cope and

their favor. This exhibition of
forward passing was, without
doubt, the best ever seen in this
part of the country and is indicative of what can be done with
such a method of attack, executed
as it was Saturday.
Sincere criticism was made of
our defense against this play
Saturday as was of our failure
to utilize such an attack, and in
justice to the team some explanation is necessary. Forward passing requires careful and persistent practice, and most of all it requires daylight. Dr. Bennett, the
Haverford coach, infoimed the
writer that hours were spent on
this play before it was perfected
and that he considered it useless
to try to practice it after dark.
To be sure, our team is equipped
with forward-pass plays, and ones
the efficacy of which has been well
tested, but the daylight needed
for their perfection is lacking.
Had we the power of Joshua, conditions might be altered, but as
it is, our forward-pass practice is
held under most unpromising conditions. The same requisites are
needed for defense against the

A Great Part of Last Year's Lacrosse
Team Can Take the Field Again.
Schedule to Be Soon
Announced.

The lacrosse team will hold its
organization meeting immediately
after the close of the football season, probably some time during
the first week in December. Light
practice in goal shooting and
stickwork to get the men in condition will be held in the cage
until after the Christmas holidays, when the hard work will
begin.
The outlook for the team this
year is'unusually bright eleven
men who have already won their
"H's" in lacrosse remain in the
University, and will be eligible
for the league games, in which
there is a four-year rule. These
men are: Capt. J. C. Knipp, exCapt. Paul Sutton, Stuart, Baker,
Brooks, Meyer, Schmidt, Woodward, Wolfe, Hoffman and F. Sutton. These men, with several of
last year's substitutes and new
men who have entered the University this fall, should make an
exceptionally strong combination,
fully up to the standards of Hopkins' teams of the past.
Manager Randolph Smith has
not yet announced his schedule,
but he will publish it in THE
NEWS-LETTER as SOOR as all the
details are arranged. According
to the custom of the lacrosse
league, Hopkins will play Swarthmore at Swarthmore this year,
while Lehigh comes to Baltimore.
GLEE CLUB STILL HAS OPEN
PLACES FOR NEW MATERIAL

The Glee Club rehearsals have
been evidencing highly satisfactory progress of late, but there
is still a shortage of men which
the director wishes'to decrease before he picks the singers who will
have fixed places in the club. As
soon as the club is picked, no
changes will be made, each member remaining in it throughout the
whole concert season. Rehearsals
for the present are held in the
large assembly hall of the Civil
Engineering Building at 8 o'clock
every Thursday evening.
In the last few rehearsals the
Hopkins songs to be sung in the
coming concerts have been reviewed and preparations have
been made for the learning of
some new classical pieces. The
management is working out an
excellent schedule for the year.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 20, 1916.

WANTS CHANGE IN AGREEMENT

MANY OUT FOR BASKETBALL TEAM

U.of Va.Asks Debating Council to Agree
to Alteration of the Conditions of
Triangle—Hopkins Insists Upon
Present Stipulations.

All Positions W111 Be Hotly Contested
Season Opens December 16, with a
Game at the Naval Academy,
Annapolis.

At the first meeting of the Debate Council last Wednesday,
what was expected to be a mere
formal ratification of the triangular debate which has been in existence for four years between the
universities of North Carolina
and Virginia and Hopkins developed into an important discussion on just how to meet a telegram from Virginia which asked
for fundamental changes in the
present agreement.
Since the triangle was founded,
it has been the invariable custom
for each university to send out
two teams, neither of which debated on its home territory. The
objects of this system were the
insuring of impartial debates, the
facilitating of the selection of
judges, and the establishment of
broader and more intimate relations between the three universities. These conditions have
proved exceptionally satisfactory
in the past, and their fairness has
been so evident, that the agreement was printed in full in a recent Intercollegiate Debate Book
as a model for the use of other institutions. During the past three
years, each debating season has
been begun by a quick ratification
of this agreement by all three universities. Just before the meeting
of the Council last week, however,
Dr. French received a telegram
from the Univeisity of Virginia,
asking that this year the agreement be so modified as to permit
one team from each university to
debate on its own ground.
After consultation, the Hopkins
Council came to the unanimous
argeement that such a change, in
their opinion, was inadvisable,
and a night letter to that effect
was immediately dispatched to
Virginia. No answer to that letter has as yet been received, and
it is therefore not known whether
Virginia will withdraw its request, or whether it will insist
upon the new conditions, even to
the breaking up of the triangle.
With the night letter to Virginia, a letter was dispatched to
North Carolina, asking if the
agreement was still satisfactory
to that university. As no objection from that quarter has been
heard, the Council deems it probable that the authorities at
Chapel Hill are behind the agreement as it stands, which fact, if
it be confirmed, will strengthen
Hopkins' position considerably.
While desirous that the triangle be continued, if possible, under the old conditions, Hopkins
has nothing to fear even were it
to be dissolved. The record of
three successive victories which it
holds will insure it debates with
other colleges and universities of

The Hqpkins Independent Basket-ball Team is well on the road
to organization. The schedule is
almost complete, and the available material for the team is of
an exceptionally fine calibre.
Since last week many playei.s
not considered in the original list
have told Pfitsch, captain and
manager, that they intended to
come out. Among these are Love,
a forward and captain of last
year's sophomore team; Joe Branham, who played guard on the
Washington College team for several seasons; Smith, a center from
Randolph Macon College; Littman, a guard on last year's City
College team; Wood, a forward
from Swarthmore Preparatory
School; and Cashell, formerly a
forward on the Rockhill High
School five.
Practice will begin some time
this week for those men that are
not out for the football team. A
place in which to practice has
been secured, but for the present
the name of the hall will only be
announced to the players.
In addition to the games that
were announced in last week's issue of THE NEWS-LETTER, another
contest has been booked. The independents will play the Naval
Academy at Annapolis on December 16. This will be the opening
game of the season, which will
continue until April 1.
While the present lineup of the
five is a remarkably good one
—with Brooks and Cox, guards;
Pfitsch, center; and Shureich and
Buchness playing the forward positions—several of the new men
are brilliant players and a hot
fight for the positions is expected.
Six or seven men will be carried
on all of the trips.
Menorah Study Circles Flourishing.

The Johns Hopkins Menorah
Society is having an unusually
successful season. At the first
meeting, there was an attendance
of almost fifty, and more are expected at the second. Two study
circles, these in modern Hebrew,
are already well under way; the
third, due to the conflict between
its hour and the time of the
Wednesday mass-meetings, has
been deferred until after Thanksgiving.

which they are in favor, the entire
discussion should be dropped
automatically, and the board be
left free to follow its policy. If
the class decides that they wish
the traditional nature of the Hullabaloo to be preserved,the change
in policy should be revoked. In
either case, before the Hullabaloo
board proceeds further with its
plan, it should correct what, in
either eventuality, has been a
grave misconception of function—
it should discover the sentiment
of the men who elected it.
In such a class discussion, one
thing must be borne in mind. The
book which will be published at
the end of the year will be either
a senior class book or it will be
an undergraduate annual. The
issue is clear-cut—and it must be
so presented by the Hullabaloo
board. The Hullabaloos of the
past have represented all University activities, and yet have been
senior books; a change from the
policy under which those books
were conceived, a change which
has been deemed important enough
to be announced individually to
every undergraduate, cannot be
misinterpreted. A book conceived
as an undergraduate annual cannot,.in the nature of things, still
be a senior book. The members of
the Class of 1917 must pass a vote
of approval or disapproval upon
the policy of the Hullabaloo
board, but, what is more important, they should have made clear
to them exactly upon what they
are voting.
The question is too vital a one
to permit of ambiguity or of misunderstanding. If 1917 is to issue
an annual instead of a class book,
it must be done so with a full
knowledge on the part of every
man of the difference which lies
between the two.
In the opinion of THE NEWSLETTER, the reason for the entire
change of policy meditated by the
1917 Hullabaloo Board is amply
explained by one phrase — "Hopkins' traditions are nil." In that
phrase is expressed the great
danger which, more than any
other, the Hopkins of the future
will have to overcome. The Hopkins undergraduates of the past,
it is true, have never worn little
black and blue caps during their
freshman years, nor have their
senior classes published books resplendent in myriad photographs
and pages. But the Hopkins of
the past has meant something,
meant something far too important to be nullified by the opinions
of any board or of any class. It
has not been a matter of the obvious, flaunting customs of the
typical small college; it has been
a matter of outlook, of understanding, of appreciation. The
thing against which Hopkins has
to guard today is not a matter of
growing too slowly, it is a matter
of growing too fast. Discardance
is too perilously easy; the need of
the Hopkins of today is preservation.

A Matter for Class Action.

takes great
pleasure in publishing, on another
page, the letter from the editorin-chief of the Hullabaloo—both
for the obvious consideration of

that, with that letter, the entire

Devoid of all argument and rhetoric, the facts of the situation
are as follows: (1) Basing its decision upon the premises that
"Hopkins has never had a creditable year book" and that "Hopkins traditions are nil," the 1917
Hullabaloo Board has planned to

the book is to be changed from

Neither the change in nature or in

In this last fact lies the crux
of the situation. An alteration in

editors of the Hullabaloo are always responsible. If that class decides that the change is one of
THE NEWS-LETTER

The Hullabaloos of the past
have had a definite meaning—
they have not been publications
whose success has been measured
by their sale. They have been
books which have meant something to the few, rather than
meant nothing to the many. They
have represented the classes by
whom they were published, as the
Hullabaloo of 1917 should represent the class by whom it is published, and, in so doing, they have
represented the spirit of the University far better than could
have—an undergraduate annual.
The change of policy of their
Hullabaloo is a matter to be decided by the. Class of 1917.
Whether 1917 experiment in
change or whether it does not,
THE NEWS-LETTER ventures the
prophecy that the senior classes
of the future, inevitably, will revert to the old conception—a Hullabaloo of the senior class. But
to the members of the 1917 class,
the matter is none the less a vital
one, for, to them, there will be
only one Hullabaloo—it is for
them to determine whether the
book they publish is to be a book
which belongs peculiarly to them,
or a book, which, perchance, will
bring slightly increased sales as
"an undergraduate annual."
Basket-ball.

In the matfer of independent
teams, Hopkins occupies a somewhat peculiar position in that the
lack of funds at the disposal of
the Athletic Association makes
impossible the recognition of
some minor sports which, at other
universities, are fully acknowledged. This position, however, is
fully known, and the independent
teams which Hopkins produces
are viewed, not as outlaw aggregations, but rather as teams
which are undergoing a period of
probation before the expense entailed by their recognition can
be undertaken.
It is this place which the independent swimming team has occupied for the last few years, and in
which it is now to be joined by
the independent basket-ball team.
The organization of those teams
is no easy matter, and the men
who are responsible for such organization are all the more entitled to praise, in that they
know that, for some time at least,
their efforts must go unrewarded.
There is at Hopkins an unusually
large number of good basket-ball
players, and the enthusiasm with
which these players have answered
the call for volunteers is a rather
encouraging augury that if the
basket-ball team this year will not
represent the University in name
it will at least represent it in
merit.

PRIZES TO BE AWARDED
FOR BEST BOTANICAL ESSAYS

Lewis and Valentine Company,
landscape gardeners and nursery
experts, have offered prizes for
the best essays on old Suffruticosa boxwood. The amounts of the
prizes range from $100 to $25.
The winning essays will be published in a garden magazine forming a series of articles on the boxwood.
Dean Brush, who has charge of
the competition at Homewood,
will provide for the selection of
the two best essays from those
entered. The essays are to be
handed in before January 1. Material for the essay can be obtained from Doctor Johnson, of
the botanical department.
Seymour Merrick,'11, Found Dead.

Samuel Seymour Merrick, who
graduated from Johns Hopkins in
1911; died last Friday morning at
his home, 824 Park avenue. His
death was caused by asphyxiation, due to the accidental extinguishing of the fire in the gas
logs in his room. He was the son
of Dr. Samuel K. Merrick, nose
and throat specialist, and the
brother of William S. Merrick,
also a Hopkins graduate; and
Robert G. Merrick, of this year's
senior class. While at Hopkins,
Seymour Merrick was one of the
most popular men in the studentbody.

COMPANIES TO BE RE-FORMED
Lack of Men Will Necessitate Reduction
of Battalion from Four Companies to
Three—Uniforms Will Probably
Arrive This Week.

The orders for the uniforms of
all the men in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps who have
paid for them were sent in last
Saturday, and it is hoped that
they will arrive before the St
John's game. As soon as the uni
forms arrive, three companies will
be formed in place of the four
now existing.
On last Friday two drills were
held so that all men desiring to
go to the Polytechnic-City College
game could do so. Besides the
regular drill at 4.30 one was held
in the morning at 7.55. r.
A great part of the time- recently has been spent in perfecting battalion drill. The movements have not been executed
with the precision that might be
expected, but it is hoped that a
high degree of excellence will
soon be attained.
It has been published in a recent bulletin of the War Department that the next examinations
of candidates for provisional appointment as second lieutenant
in the line of the Army, will begin on January 29, 1917.
Applicants for authority to
take this examination should
forward their applications to the
Adjutant-General of the Army at
as early a date as practicable,
and in any event, in time to reach
the Adjutant-General's office not
later than January 15, 1917, as
applications received after that
date may be too late for proper
consideration in connection with
the examination.
As there are now a large number of vacancies in the Army,
this examination offers an excellent opportunity for men between
the ages of 21 and 27 to enter as
second lieutenants. -The pay of a
second lieutenant is $1,700 yearly.
Another appeal has been made
for more enlistments. If 60 more
men would enroll, the reorganization of the battalion into three
companies would be unnecessary.
It is hoped that a large number
of the physical exercise class and
the football candidates will enroll in the near future.
The University of St. Louis has
adopted a novel form of freNknansophomore contest. The rules provide for a seven-foot wood stockade surrounding a 14-foot wooden
flagpole, upon which the sophomores will place their banner. In
breaking into this stockade, in
which the sophomores are stationed, the freshmen will not be
allowed to use battering rams or
weapons of any description. The
sophomores are to be provided
with ropes.—Ex.

Some very interesting moving
pictures of the American Ambulance Corps in field service will

in the lecture hall of
be
Engineering Building
l
Civi
the
the'
on Tuesday, November 28, at 5
o'clock.
The pictures were taken by the
French Government and were presented to the American Ambulance Field Service in appreciation and recognition of its excellent assistance in attending to the
wounded. At present there are
about two hundred American ambulances in the French Army,
which are divided into four sections—one in Flanders, one in Alsace, one in the Somme region
and one at Verdun. They are supported largely by wealthy gitizens
of the United States.
The entire operation of the ambulances is carried on by students
from many of our big universities, such as Harvard, Yale and
Princeton. So excellent have been
their services that many have
been awarded "the Cross of War"
or the "Military Medal"—honors
not easily won. Moreover, they
have been appointed the official
lifters of the wounded on account
of their gentleness and ability.
Three of the Baltimore boys are
Emory Niles, Leonard Ober and
Johnson Okrick.
Consequent to their invaluable
aid, the French Government wants
another section to post at Saloniki and in order to fulfill this,
desire, the American Ambulance
Field Service is endeavoring to recruit more men.
In order to attain that end,
these moving pidures are being
shown in the United States, with
the hope that a large number of
young men will offer their serv
ices to the corps. The pictures are
being shown in Baltimore under
the auspices of the local committee of the American Fund for
French Wounded, of which Miss
Louise Dawson is chairman. This
society is affiliated with the
American Ambulance Field Service.
Besides the exhibition, on next
Tuesday at Homewood, the moving pictures will be also displayed
at the Johns Hopkins Medical
School and at the Lyceum Theater
on this Friday at 8.30. On the
latter occasion, Mr. Lisle Buswell
will speak on the work • of the
corps and will tell of his experiences at the front.
It is the hope of these societies
that a large number of Hopkins •
men will see these pictures of
their fellow-students at the front,
and that sonic will enlist in the
American Ambulance Field Service.
A bequest of $20,000 has been
left to the University of Oberlin
to enable the student body to hear
the finest speakers that can be
procured.—Ex.
